text: TOM SHAW and DAN BENNET, seated on the edge of a coffee table in this RURAL APARTMENT, uncomfortably close TO us -- staring AT us.

Okay, Richard. I’m going to hand you this phone now... Shaw is 45. Grim as hell, he dials a PHONE, hands it TO us. We are: INT. BOBI’S APT. (GEORGIA) - DAY (1996) RICHARD JEWELL, seated opposite them on a sofa, eyes the phone. He’s 34, Georgian, shy, stocky, unathletic (and -- if these feds are right -- a killer, a mad bomber).
When you hear a BEEP on the other end, I want you to say into it, ‘There is a bomb in Centennial Park. You have thirty minutes.’
I’m sorry, what?
We need a voice exemplar. Like ya to say it a few times.
‘There is a bomb in Centennial Park. You have thirty minutes.’ Might be the only way to clear your name, Richard.
I wanna help you fellas. I’m law enforcement, too, same as you.

Then you should know better than anyone else how evidentiary something like this could be. (as Jewell tightens) ‘There is a bomb in Centennial Park. You have thirty minutes.’ Might be the only way to clear your name, Richard. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 2.
It’s not a request. Then, quietly -- steels himself. There Park. Good. There Park. Again series. The phone BEEPS. Jewell takes it,
(into phone) is a bomb in Centennial You have thirty minutes.
Again, please. Louder.
(into phone) is a bomb in Centennial You have thirty minutes.
In fact, let’s just doa Jewell tightens, perspiring. We PUSH IN ON HIM as: There Park. There Park. There Park. There Park. There

bomb have bomb have bomb have bomb have in Centennial thirty minutes. in Centennial thirty minutes. in Centennial thirty minutes. in Centennial thirty minutes. SLAM CUT TO BLACK. 10 YEARS EARLIER -- 1986 -- ATLANTA, GA.

Jewell, 50 clipboard in hand, carefully catalogues AISLES of pens, tape, etc. Supplies are his domain. He wears a uniform top and khakis.  RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 3. INT. U.S. SMALL BUSINESS ADMIN. - SUITE/BRYANT’S OFFICE -

Jewell pushes his SUPPLY CART through the suite like an unseen shadow -- offering a shy smile to all he sees. He’s just passing by some lawyer’s OPEN OFFICE DOOR, when: -.. he hears half of a PHONE CONVERSATION from within -- that UNSEEN LAWYER shredding someone:

I don’t GIVE a damn! You are violating the most basic and sacred rights of business owner who doesn’t have the means to fight you! So I’m going to fight you. And I’m going to bury you until you do right by her! Whoever this guy is, he’s fearless. Jewell stays in place.

Listen, if you wanna threaten me, do it to my face. We’re at 233 Peachtree. 19th floor. C’mon by, we validate. (then; calmly) Good talking to you, too, Senator. Senator? Whoa. The call ends, Jewell FROZEN outside the door. He starts to push his CART away, just as -- oh, no Unseen Lawyer, WATSON BRYANT, leans out of that office:
Who are you? Bryant is 35, a Southern preppy in a three-piece suit. Jewell tightens, caught.
I’m Richard, sir. I’m sorry I was listening. I don’t want you to think I’m rude. I’m not like that.
You always start every sentence with ‘I’? Jewell reddens a bit, Bryant enjoying the guy’s torment. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 4.
Sorry. I’m the supply room clerk.
Good. I need some more ta--
-- Second drawer of your desk, sir. Tape and a new box of pens. Huh? Bryant crosses to his DESK, opens the second drawer. Tape awaits. And a new box of pens. He eyes Jewell.
Saw you were running low. Look in the next drawer down. Bryant opens the bottom drawer. Five SNICKERS BARS stare back at him. He studies Jewell, almost spooked.
How'd you know I liked Snickers?
Saw wrappers in your trash can.
Richard, from now on, your name is ‘Radar.’ That felt like a compliment. Jewell half-smiles...

Jewell fires a GUN -- his stance professional, his focus singular and sober, his eyes cold. BANG! BANG! But: The gun is PLASTIC, and he’s firing at a VIDEO SCREEN -- the only adult in this MALL ARCADE filled with KIDS. Down goes a bad guy, then another. BELLS RING! He’s just set a “NEW RECORD SCORE!” Kids in here turn. One of them (JASPER, 10) eyes Jewell: TEACH ME! PLEASE!
(still firing) I leave the blue invaders be. Waste of ammo.
Whoa. Thanks... (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 5.

That’s Jewell: an arcade hero. He glances to his right and FREEZES awkwardly -- just saw someone entering: It's Bryant, entering this same arcade -- a large soda from Chick-fil-A in hand. Bryant pauses, wasn’t expecting to see Jewell here. But now he’d look like a shit if he walked away, so... He reluctantly drifts toward Jewell, who fires again.
Nice shooting, Radar. Come here often?
It’s practice for my career in law enforcement, sir. APD, FBI.
What the hell would ya wanna do that for? An instant distaste for authority. Jewell notes it.
Believe in protectin’ people, sir. Bryant puts coins in the neighboring machine, starts firing. That fast, they’re side-by-side, semi-competing.
I study the Penal Code every night.
Is that so? (keeps firing) What’s the violation number for public intoxication?
OCGA 16-11-1, sir.
(mildly threatened) Domestic battery?
Jewell is rattling all of this off while kicking Bryant’s ass in the video game. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 6.
You’re pretty methodical.

I do like to go from A to B to C to D. This going from A straight to D and arguing over everything, I say no. Bryant’s GAME ends. Jewell throws a quick look at Bryant’s score, trying to be charitable.
That’s pretty good, for a first time.
First time? Ya know what? Bryant reaches into his pocket, pulls out EIGHT QUARTERS, slams them down. A challenge. Jewell notes them.
They only gimme a half-hour for lunch, sir.
You can say you were with me. He pumps another quarter into the machine. Game on. We DROP -—
LOOKING IN on them -- two “grown men” in a video shootout. Loving it...
Jewell, no cart tonight, drifts through the STACKS -- law books, criminal codes. Then he STOPS:
Mister Bryant? REVEAL Bryant, at a table, reading. He looks up, annoyed.
Yes? (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 7.
I’m not gonna be workin’ here anymore. Came t’say bye. (off Bryant's surprised) I got a new job in security. Start tomorrow.
That’s great, Radar! It’s law enforcement, like you wanted.
Yeah. My mom’s taking me out tonight to buy some neckties and stuff. Gotta dress right.
I suppose you do.

Goin’ to T.J. Maxx. Anyway, thanks. For everything -- He starts toward Bryant, who tightens. Is he going to hug me? Ask me to adopt him? Bryant bracing -- But Jewell simply lays something on the table -- A SNICKERS BAR. Bryant stares at it.
Saw you were running low... Jewell’s shy, odd kindness again. Bryant eyes him.
Ya got enough money, Richard? For all those neckties you need?
I guess. Bryant extracts his wallet and pulls out a $100 bill. Jewell’s eyes go wide. Bryant hands the $100 to Jewell.
I don’t underst--
This comes with a quid pro quo. Ya know what that is?
Yeah, Latin. This for that. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 8.
That's right. Fair exchange. So, here it is: When you get your badge -- and I can see that day is coming -- don’t become an asshole.
Huh? Why would I become an...
A little power can turn a person into a monster, Richard. Don’t let that happen to you. Understand? Jewell has NO idea how to respond. Bryant just stares.
I’‘ll get this back to you, sir. First paycheck. I promise. Bryant breathes out a disappointed/ironic smile, well aware that nothing he said has sunk in.

TIGHT SHOTS of a COP: Badge. Maglite. Nightstick. Danner APB police boots. Taser. SIDEARM. Serious shit. He is: Jewell, 10 YEARS LATER, the most serious CAMPUS COP ever, scowling his way down a DORMITORY HALLWAY toward a room. SUPERIMPOSE: 1996 -- PIEDMONT UNIVERSITY. DEMOREST, GA. He raps on ROOM 201’s door with his NIGHTSTICK. We hear the SHATTERING of a BOTTLE within. And drunk LAUGHTER as:
You dumbass!
I got flustered! Get the door! They crack up. Jewell raps again; doesn’t think drinking on campus is funny. At all. The door opens, but -- STUDENT #1 sees Jewell and SHUTS THE DOOR AGAIN. We hear:
It’s that rent a cop! (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 9.
Shit! A beat. Jewell waiting. The door opens again... and:

Yes, Officer? Jewell doesn’t speak -- just pushes the door open with his NIGHTSTICK, very Clint Eastwood... then enters. Silence. The broken BOTTLE OF SCOTCH lies on the floor. He notes the BEER POSTERS on the walls. Shakes his head, brushes aside a chunk of wet glass with his police boot. And the kids lose it, laughing aloud. Jewell really hates that. He gets in Student #1’s face, too close:
Somethin’ you wanted t’say?
Yes, are you familiar with the notion of unlawful search and --

-- Keep pushing me. Keep testing me. See if you like where it gets you. Jewell leans in. Student #1 steps back, but slips and falls backward to the floor. THUMP. He’s unhurt -- but Jewell is instantly panicked: I almost hurt someone. Silence hangs. The kids don’t know what to do. Jewell tries to cover with bravado, but it’s an act:

I told you, no drinking on my campus. Remember? Now get up. INT. PIEDMONT COLLEGE - CLEERE’S OFFICE - DAY Jewell sits opposite DR. W. RAY CLEERE, 60, the PRESIDENT of this college. Cleere studies Jewell’s thick FILE.

I don’t know why no one called my attention to your file before. All these complaints about you. Physically assaulting a student. And have you really been pulling people over on the highway? (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 10.
Yes, I have, sir. Figured if you do drunk tests on the road, the trouble never gets to the campus.
We don’t have any jurisdiction on the highway.
I believe in law and order, sir. Can't have a country without it.
(re: file) You were dismissed from the Habersham County Sheriff's Office?
-- You said you didn’t want any Mickey-Mousing on your campus.
When did I say that?

Founders’ Day, last year. Remember, sir? By the punch bowl. I introduced myself and told you I was gonna be the best campus officer you ever saw. You said, ‘That’s fine. I don’t want any Mickey-Mousing on these grounds.’ Jewell takes out his OFFICIAL NOTEPAD, opens it:
‘No Mickey-Mousing on these grounds.’ See? You said it. Now, what about the kids in that dormitory, drinkin’ and everything? You just gonna let that go on?
Do you want to resign -- or would it be better if I fired you?
Meet DAVE DUTCHESS blasting away with a DEER RIFLE. Jewell’s in the next lane with a Rambo-worthy SIG-400 ASSAULT RIFLE. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 11.
It was a shit job anyway, hassling college brats. ‘Sides, there’s gonna be so much security work the next couple months, you’re set.
I worked hard at that job. Those kids were just runnin’ wild.
Olympics're comin’, brother. You can police the whole world!

A DEAD MAN lies in an ALLEY. Stab wounds all over him. KATHY SCRUGGS eyes the body dispassionately. She’s 35, beauty-pageant pretty. Blonde hair, blue eyes. Brassy, sexy, and profane. Also a dogged and prolific reporter.
First dead body? Beside her is a YOUNG PHOTOGRAPHER who just might vomit. But Kathy looks gleeful, breathing in the ugliness.
This part is crucial. It’s called the Homicide High-Step. She straddles the body carefully, respecting the crime scene.
Don’t worry. I’ve got a gun in my glove compartment. That didn’t help. Kathy uses a PEN to peel back the victim’s COAT, revealing a disembodied FINGER.
Yep. Pinkie came clean off. That happens in stabbings sometimes. Photographer swallows a gag. Kathy loves that.
Isn’t there something pre-Olympic we could be doing right now? (CONTINUED)
10 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 12.
Honey, there’1ll be 15,000 reporters in town to cover the Games. Shouldn’t somebody tell this poor shithead’s story?
Not much for sentiment, I guess.
His disaster could be your opportunity. Now click away. Just then, a SQUAD CAR pulls up. And two COPS get out... not surprised to see that Kathy has beaten them here.
Fellas! What took y’all so long?

Welcome to the ATLANTA JOURNAL-CONSTITUTION (the “AJC”). Busy. Tense. A mounted DIGITAL CLOCK is counting down: 2 Days, 4 Hours, 6 Minutes, 32 Seconds, 31, 30... until the lighting of the torch. And this paper is ready as -- Kathy storms through the newsroom toward BRANDON HAMM.
Oh, shit. What’d he assign you?
The ‘Celebrations at Centennial Park!’ Woo-hoo. Something finally happens in this city and I get a Kenny Rogers concert!
Could be worse. Could be Equestrian.
I’m getting my tits done. Soon.
Not sure how that applies here --
By this time next year we’re all gonna be scrambling for jobs on TV. Maybe a C-cup? (CONTINUED)
10 11 12 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 13.
She does a mini-shimmy. A few FEMALE REPORTERS two desks away look on disapprovingly. Hamm smiles.
I'd miss you, Kathy. Even if they wouldn't.
(loud; at the women) Girls, I’m sorry all my hot-ass murders keep knocking your boring bullshit off the front page! (at Hamm) Wanna get a drink?
I’d only slow you down. She walks away. Hamm grins.
Tom Shaw is seething. Glaring. Just got assigned to:

‘Centennial Park’? What the fuck! INT. BRYANT’S LAW OFFICE - RECEPTION/OFFICE - MORNING 12 A cramped RECEPTION DESK manned by NADYA LIGHT: lovely, fierce, Jewish, Russian-born, has a mini TV on her desk. To her right is a COPIER IN A CLOSET. To her left is -- Bryant, in a TINY OFFICE, wearing HIKING SHORTS and a polo shirt, his receding hairline hidden under a BALL CAP. Reading a novel. His view is a BRICK WALL. No more U.S. Small Business Admin. No more 3-piece suits. A SIGN on his credenza reads, “I Fear Government More Than I Fear Terrorism.” What happened to him? Something’s off here. Nadya leans in -- she’s got a great Russian accent:
Watson, we’re out of toner.
Okay. She waits for him to understand. He doesn’t. (CONTINUED)
12 13 14 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 14.
If I go out, you’ll have to answer the phones.
Oh. I’11 go, then. Thank you.
There’s a sale at the Walmart. Ten percent off if you can name anyone from the U.S. Olympic Team.
(reflex-grumpiness ) Jesus.
I know: people smiling for sixteen days. It’s going to be awful.

No, it’s going to be WONDERFUL. For Coca-Cola, CNN... and anyone with a parking lot. Out he goes. EXT. BOBI’S APT. BLDG. - PARKING LOT/GROUNDS - DAY 13 A huge, EMPTY parking lot, ringed by low-rent two-story structures and woods. A half-empty, brush-filled swimming pool sits close by the HIGHWAY. INT. BOBI’S APT. - LIVING ROOM/KITCHEN - MORNING 14 We've been here before. A PLAQUE says, “A Home Without a Dog is just a House.” A PORTRAIT of Jewell (ina HABERSHAM COUNTY DEPUTY SHERIFF’s uniform) hangs on the wall. Jewell, in a polo shirt with an AT&T LOGO on the front -- (“SECURITY” across the back) eats a DONUT while watching a TV REPORT on MICHAEL JOHNSON, World’s Fastest Human. BARBARA “BOBI” JEWELL, mom, is baking five POUND CAKES, a side business. Her dog BRANDI hovers.
(from the kitchen) Can you believe it’s really here? An Olympics! In our city! (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 15.
(from the sofa) This is it, Momma. My one moment in time. I prove myself, somebody’11 make me a cop again.
That's right, baby. Bobi hobbles (bad foot) to the sink. Jewell drifts in.
I been thinking. I’m not gonna move out ‘til after you’ve had your surgery. You might need me around. Would that be all right?
You get goin’ now. We can tend to all that when the Games are over. But none of that heavy foot of yours driving there. No heavy foot!
I won’t, ma’am. I won’t, Mother.
‘Cause why?
‘Cause wherever I’m goin’ it’1l still be there ten minutes later.
That’s right. Give Momma a kiss. He obeys. Bobi smiles. Then, a moment of doubt --
It is law enforcement, ain’t it? Even if I’m just guardin’ a bunch of stereo equipment.
Heck, yes! You're still a good guy wardin’ off bad guys, ain’t ya?
OK mama, I’1l see you at the park. Jewell smiles; Bobi’s his rock. He starts to head out.  15 16 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 16.
REVEAL: NBC’S BROADCAST -- MUHAMMAD ALI lighting the Olympic Torch with an entire stadium cheering.
Pageantry. The Games of Atlanta, 1996, have begun. Then --

FIREWORKS light up a night sky over this park. It is the place to celebrate. Every night of these games. 60,000 PEOPLE on 21 acres rimmed by downtown high-rises. A giant neon COCA-COLA SIGN atop the tallest of them. FOUNTAINS spurt water into the air; KIDS run through. Joy. Pride. And KENNY ROGERS in concert! People dance, sing, pose for PICTURES. Shirtless men, girls in tank tops. A hot, sexy night, America hosting the world. A GUY calls out --

Bobi laughs as she sings along with “The Gambler” on stage. Clapping. So much fun. The stage is run from a SOUND AND LIGHT TOWER 100 feet away -- 5 stories of steel, covered with white plastic siding. KIDS gather here, on benches, swapping OLYMPIC PINS. But we don’t see much SECURITY. Gates are unmanned. The entries are porous. Targets everywhere, unprotected. Tom Shaw is here. So bored. And angry about it. He spots Kathy Scruggs, equally bored. Heads over.
Hello, Kathy. (CONTINUED)
16 17 18 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 17.
Welcome to the Happiest Place on Earth! Fucking nightmare. Isn’t there anything crime-y goin’ on anywhere?
Hell if I know. I’m here.
Christ. Wanna dance?
Love to, but I’m on duty.
Fuck duty. She starts to dance up against him. He grins.
Jewell, in his SECURITY GUARD shirt, lugs VIDEO EQUIPMENT up stairs behind NBC cameraman, into:
Anywhere’s fine. Thanks, man.
No trouble. You need anything else up here? SEVERAL TECHS are busily working. They wave, no thanks.
Jewell descends... to find TWO OTHER SECURITY GUARDS (ROB and LONNY) scrawling GRAFFITI on the stairwell steps.
What’re you guys doing?
Leavin’ our mark. Here’s what they wrote: “Welcome to the Coca-Cola Olympics!” And “American by Birth, Southern by the Grace of God.” (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 18.
First Olympics the South’s ever had and you guys do that? Didn’t your folks teach you any better? (as they shrug) Life’s tough. Tougher when you're stupid.
Music blares. Jewell stands guard, vigilant and alert. A PREGNANT WOMAN walks by. Jewell’s reaction is instant:
Do you need some water, ma’am?
Hmmm?
Water? It’s a warm night. He reaches UNDER a bench where HIS COOLER sits. Inside, WATER and COKES on ice. He grabs one of each.
You’re just giving ‘em away?
I keep ‘em here for pregnant women and police officers. She takes the water, a bit suspect of his Boy-Scoutness.
Thanks.
Have a good night.
Music rocking. Kathy dances, tipsy/sexy... Shaw is a few feet away, trying to scan the crowd.
Why so grim, big guy?
‘Cause I’m bored. (CONTINUED)
20 21 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 19.
We’re all bored.
Yeah, but I was born for better! Kathy laughs, keeps dancing.
Three ATLANTA PD COPS (MAX GREEN, MIKE SILVER, and WILL JONES) grouse with BILL MILLER of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI). Jewell approaches, handing them each a COKE. They nod, as:
All these athletes complainin’ ‘bout gettin’ to their venues late on account of the traffic, and I’m thinkin’, ‘What about the COPS? We can’t get anywhere, either.’
I was half-ready to run my siren last night just so I could get to the supermarket, so damn crowded. PEOPLE AMBLE PAST -- the cops barely paying attention.
It's just poor planning by the Olympic Committee. There ain’t a one of them jake-legs has got a damn clue about traffic patterns.
(knows already) Whadda you think, Richard? You think that committee’s a buncha jake-legs?

I don’t know. They got a heckuva job to do, coordinating all this. And MARTA, don’t forget. I’m glad I don’t hafta do it. (as the cops chuckle) What? It’s tough to get all this logistics right all the time.
Shit, Richard, they ain’t listening in on us. (CONTINUED)
21 22 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 20.
They laugh. Then something turns Jewell’s head: A WHITE MALE, bearing a BACKPACK, walking BY us -- LONG HAIR, tattoos beneath a TANK TOP, and sunglasses. Something about him -- and that backpack...
Hey, any’a you-all ever seen that guy before? The cops shake their heads, unalarmed. Jewell thinking.
That backpack look funny to you?
Funny how? Jewell doesn’t reply, just drifts toward the WHITE MALE. The COPS laugh. We STAY WITH JEWELL -- passing through:

No one’s on stage; “MACARENA” plays over loudspeakers, the CONCERT CROWD dancing. But not Jewell. His eyes are riveted on that WHITE MALE, bearing that BACKPACK through the thick crowd. +.. right past Kathy. And Shaw. --. Jewell gets closer, White Male reaches the barrier near the stage. Now Jewell KNOWS something’s wrong. White Male takes off his backpack, starts to unzip it. Time to move. NOW. Jewell pushes past people in the crowd. White Male pulls a BEER from the backpack. Then another beer, then two more. Oh. Jewell freezes. The White Male turns to his friends and surprises them with beers. Jewell realizes he was wrong, is embarrassed.

23 24 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 21. INT. BOBI’S APT. —- JEWELL’S ROOM/LIVING ROOM - AFTERNOON Jewell sits on his bed, ill today -- nauseous, pale, and sweaty -- wearing his AT&T SECURITY shirt. Bobi watches more Olympic coverage: TOM BROKAW of NBC.
My, he is handsome. You don’t want a sandwich or anything, Baby?
Naw, I don’t feel well, Momma. My stomach.
Somethin’ you ate?
Guess so.
Why you eat at those places... He eyes this tiny apartment, angry at himself...
What, baby?
Nothin’. Just... World owes you better ‘n this, Momma.
World owes us both. But this is what we got. Now go do your job. Bobi pulls him close.

Another 60,000-PERSON PARTY, like an Olympic Town Square. On stage, JACK MACK AND THE HEART ATTACK are playing. Jewell stands his post at the tower, nearly doubled over from cramps. Officer Green kids him about it:
This could be a good thing.
Yeah? How? (CONTINUED)
24 25 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 22.
We could bring you out to the diving venue and have you fart the Chinese National Anthem. (as Jewell’s a blank) Why don’t you switch shifts with someone? Go home?
This is my favorite band. I’m okay.
Jack Mack is your favorite band?

I‘ll be fine. The raucous crowd cheers. Feels like the whole world is celebrating. Jewell runs off, hurting -- as we: A FAMILY drifts by: The BRADENS -- MOM, DAD, JERROD (8), MARIAH (6). A cotton-candy dream of a night for them.
(gymnastic leap) Look, Mommy! I’m Kerri Strug!
Hold it! Do that again. He grabs his video camera. Mariah happily performs. Mom and dad beam, just a few feet from Jewell’s bench. We SEE THE VIDEO THEY’RE SHOOTING -- dark, grainy. Then:
Jewell, in knots, cramping, runs up to Bill Miller of
I’ll be back.

Go! Miller chuckles. Jewell runs for a RESTROOM -- +.. right past Tom Shaw, who is ever-watchful... as: Outside the sound and light tower -- Mariah hams it up for the camera. Her brother Jerrod, too, stag-leaping, as: (CONTINUED)
25 26 27 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 23.
Look, Dad! I’m Mitch Gaylord! Dad, right in front of Jewell’s BENCH, tapes it all.

Jewell hurries through the crowd -- passing a GAY COUPLE, two MUSLIMS, a SIKH, a MIXED-RACE COUPLE kissing. Foreign LANGUAGES in the air. A BEER gets spilled on his shirt by DRUNK PARTIERS who don’t even notice. Jewell tightens and continues along, invisible among the music, the energy, the joy.
Little Jerrod does another stag-leap beside his sister.

Okay. Enough gymnastics? He heads toward them... We notice something, unattended: A MILITARY BACKPACK laying under Jewell’s BENCH. It’s BIG, olive green. (The Army calls them ALICE PACKS.) Mariah just noticed it. She drifts toward it, curious... reaches out to touch it as --
‘Scuse me. Jewell, returning to his post. Mrs. Braden looks up --
Mariah! You leave that alone. It isn’t yours to play with! Mariah stiffens. Jewell smiles at her.

Better listen to your ma. Mariah obeys. Jewell now a foot from the ALICE PACK as: SOUNDS echo from the FENCE BEHIND THE AT&T TOWER: drunken LAUGHTER and BOTTLES BREAKING. Jewell heads around the tower. We FOLLOW... to find: TEN DRUNK TEENS throwing empty beer bottles at the back of the sound and light tower. Laughing. (CONTINUED)
27 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 24.
Hey, y’all gotta stop doin’ that. They regard him: a heavyset guy in an AT&T shirt.
What’re you gonna do, cancel my phone service? His buddies laugh. A TV CAMERA CREW passes by. The Drunks holler, trying to get the crew’s attention.
Put us on TV! The crew ignores them. Jewell stays on task:
The cops aren’t gonna ask as nicely. They get you for drunk and disorderly, that’s cuffs anda night in the lockup.
They'd have to CATCH me first. Which ain’t gonna happen.
Oh, yeah?
I’m Michael Johnson, world’s fastest man. Wanna see my medal? MORE HUGE LAUGHS. This is a goner. Jewell turns -- walks back around the tower toward Bill Miller of GBI.

Hey, I got some drunks back there breaking bottles on the tower. Maybe they’11 listen to you. (as Miller groans) People respect a badge. Miller goes... which is when Jewell STOPS... and NOTICES That ALICE PACK under his bench. It’s BIG. Very. He studies it, his face blank -- then calls out to Miller:
And see if any of ‘em left a backpack under my bench. (CONTINUED)
27 28 29 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 25.
What is it with you and backpacks? Jewell shrugs, regarding the ALICE pack. Miller goes...
A slow night -- as a 9-1-1 OPERATOR takes a call:
(into headset) 9-1-1. She hears a MALE VOICE through a BAFFLING DEVICE:
(through headset) Can you understand me?
(into headset) Yes.
(through headset) You defy the order of the militia.
(into headset) What? CLICK. Operator shrugs, annoyed. Back to work.
Jewell stares at that ALICE PACK. The concert is just b.g. noise now. He checks his WATCH as Miller returns:
It ain’t theirs.
No? Miller shakes his head. They look around: THOUSANDS of people out here, dancing. But no one close enough to belong to that backpack.
Okay. We got a suspicious package. Better call it in. (CONTINUED)
29 30 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 26.
Miller eyes it, unalarmed. But Jewell seems so sure...
Probably just somebody run off drunk and forgot they left it.
Yeah. Let’s call it in anyway.
Shouldn't we unzip it and see what's in there first?
I wouldn’t. There’s a protocol. Miller steps toward it... But the closer he gets to the ALICE pack, the bigger it looks. So he STOPS, irritated.
Son of a bitch had to get left under your bench, didn’t it. He grabs his radio. Jewell approaches Green of APD:
We got a suspicious package -- need to clear these people out.
Hang on, hang on. What package? Jewell nods toward the ALICE pack. Green eyes it.
Probably nothing.
Yeah, but... Need a perimeter.
Shit, Richard. Could be just filled with BEER?
It ain’t beer. I know it. Jewell eyes that TOWER -- the ALICE pack sitting up against its base -- and he heads inside. Green sighs.
Jewell rushes in to the SOUND ROOM where FOUR TECHS barely look up from the board. (CONTINUED)
30 31 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 27.
We have a situation downstairs. Need you guys to get out of here.
What kinda situation?
A suspicious package in front of the tower. Law enforcement is aware of it and on the scene.
Well, if the cops tell us we have to go, we'll go. (as Jewell eyes them) Band's in the middle of a set. We can’t just shut down.
I come back here, there’ll be no questions, no hesitation. You're just gettin’ the hell out, yeah? Everyone nods. He counts the heads in the room. FOUR.
The 10 DRUNK TEENS eye the ALICE pack, NO IDEA that it’s the reason the cops need a perimeter.
I think we should take it.
Fuckin’ A.
I think we should take it to the House of Blues, and see if there’s anything in it we can sell.
Clutch idea. Drunk #1 reaches down, GRABS THE ALICE PACK --

Hey! You leave that alone and get out of here! Drunk #1 releases the ALICE pack. But in the process he moves it without meaning to so it’s no longer sitting up.  32 33 34 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 28.
Cameraman and a TEEN INTERN here. Jewell enters.
Need you to clear out. Got a bomb scare in front of the tower. That got the Teen’s attention, fast. He stands.
We get bomb threats all the time in D.C. They’re never anything.
Cool for you. But I’m outta here. The kid leaves. Cameraman grabs his CAMERA, follows.
Kathy sits on a wall, awaiting a shuttle bus. Bored. RON MARTZ (former Marine, fellow reporter) comes by.
Local cop discovered yesterday that he’s actually second-cousins with a Polish gymnast. Is that a story?
Doesn’t get me hard.
I know. Me neither. Kathy shakes her head.
Jewell emerges, sees Silver of APD. The CONCERT in b.g.
Got eleven people still inside.
You know this is a false alarm. Jewell smiles thinly as a BOMB DIAGNOSTIC TEAM arrives. Two guys, ZOELLER and FORSYTHE, in shorts, as:  35 36 37 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 29.
Another call comes in:
(into headset) 9-1-1. Same MALE VOICE -- this time pinching his nose:
(through headset) There is a bomb in Centennial Park. You have thirty minutes. CLICK. He hangs up. Huh? OPERATOR #2 punches something into her computer, then turns, confused, to OPERATOR #3:
Do you know the address to Centennial Park? I just got this man talking about there’s a bomb set to go off in thirty minutes in Centennial Park. But the computer won't process it.
What? Lord, child. You spelling it wrong. It’s C-E-N-T-E-N...
A MAN wearing a FISHERMAN’S HAT, his BACK TO us, hangs up the receiver at a BANK OF 10 PAY PHONES and walks away...
ALICE HAWTHORNE and her daughter FALLON (14) are beside the sound and light tower -- Fallon posing for a picture. Jewell approaches, calm but firm:
Folks, need you to move away from the tower, please... Huh? Alice looks around, sees Officers Green, Silver, Jones, and Miller quietly moving people away. Odd.
I’m getting tired, Mom. (CONTINUED)
37 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 30.
Me, too. Let’s take the last of these pictures and go home. Off they go, unfazed. No one out here looks alarmed. Jewell approaches PARTIERS on a knoll behind the tower.
Need you folks to clear the area, please. Need a perimeter here.

You go, Richard! Jewell keeps at it. We DRIFT TOWARD THE BENCH, where -- Bomb-team-guy Zoeller lies on his back, looking at the ALICE pack with a PENLIGHT. Opens the flap, slowwwwwwly. THREE PIPES inside. And wires. A BOMB. Oh, fuck. Zoeller FREEZES, then inches away from the bomb, his arms never moving from that same position -- Gets to his partner, FAST. Jewell notices. They all do.
They told us in training: ‘You ever see a bomb guy go pale, RUN.’
Amen, brother. Zoeller and Forsythe consult in hushed tones... Jewell and the COPS drifting in. Then Zoeller turns:
We have three pipe bombs inside that pack, big as I’ve ever seen. I want a hundred-foot perimeter cleared immediately. Oh. The cops eye one another.
You guys got a bomb blanket or -- ?
The Render-Safe team can be here in 20 minutes. He steps away to radio it in. Everyone standing still. (CONTINUED)
37 38 39 40 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 31.
Richard, I’m never givin’ you shit about anything ever again.
You said it, bubba.
Let’s just go to work. The COPS find a different gear now, fanning out urgently. Jewell has one thought: the people inside that tower.
Jewell bursts in. The same TECHS are at the soundboard.
You guys gotta get outta here. NOW. (as everyone freezes) We've got a bomb. NOW. Three guys head out. A FOURTH GUY tries to gather a bunch of VIDEOTAPES. Jewell pulls him away.
Y'hear? Down the stairs! Go! Fourth guy heads for the stairs. We RETURN TO:
Jewell bursts in, finds a GUY WORKING A SPOTLIGHT.
We're evacuating. Go. Spotlight guy starts to power his equipment down -- but Jewell GRABS HIM, pushes him to the door.
Go! Pushing him into the STAIRWELL -- SHOT CONTINUING -- where Jewell looks down, counts 11 PEOPLE descending...
Alice Hawthorne poses for a shot in front of a BRASS STATUE. Her daughter Fallon frames it up. (CONTINUED)
40 41 42 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 32.
Smile! Alice smiles. Fallon takes the picture. But:
I blinked. Take another one! Fallon lifts the camera again... EXT. CENTENNIAL PARK - THE CROWD — SAME TIME 41 People dancing, partying.
Urgent movement. COPS SHOUTING, people moving back. Tom Shaw is part of the effort now. Jewell emerges from the Sound and Light tower. He spots Green:
Building’s clear.
You should get outta here, Richard.
Uh-huh. You, too. They both start pushing people back, but folks are slow to respond. It’s a party, isn’t it? Behind the tower, Jewell comes upon a NECKING COUPLE.
Need you two to clear outta here. They keep kissing. We RETURN TO:
... where the ALICE pack sits...
Fallon taking a last picture of her mother... (CONTINUED)
42 43 44 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 33.

Shaw, Miller, urging people to move, when -- INT. BOBI’S APT. - BEDROOM - SAME TIME 43 Bobi is sound asleep. Suddenly, her eyes SNAP OPEN -- as if startled by an urgent and horrible dream. She gasps --
Richard...
JEWELL -- behind the tower, moving in on that couple while checking his WATCH --

I’m not kidding. Y'all gotta -- Just then, BOOOOM! A CONCUSSIVE EXPLOSION. DEATH ITSELF. And the world just STOPS. Jewell and the couple are knocked flat. (But the tower itself has protected them.) We -- CUT TO BLACK.

For a moment -- a feeling of surreality. The SOUND OF SHRAPNEL SIZZLING PAST US like rifle fire, eerie... Then we HEAR -- SCREAMS. TERROR. We're blind, until we SLAM UP ON -- Jewell’s eyes opening foggily. He turns, in SLOW MOTION, and sees a HORROR: COPS FLYING THROUGH THE AIR -- Miller, Green, Silver, Jones, Shaw -- And Jewell’s BENCH, rocketing upwards. SMOKE pluming. The SIDING torn off the AT&T tower -- and worst of all -- ALICE HAWTHORNE -- spinning in a 360, then falling. (CONTINUED)
44 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 34.

Then... an unearthly SILENCE. END SLOW MOTION as we bleed in more sounds of SCREAMS, PANIC, terror, confusion. Good God. Pieces of NAILS start falling to the ground like noisy drops of rain. PING. TING. PING-TING. The kissing couple beside Jewell is catatonic, barely breathing.

You two okay? You okay? They nod, sort of. He crawls away -- around the tower -- to find sheer, bloody carnage -- a BATTLEFIELD: WOUNDED everywhere. COPS laid out. People senseless. Alice Hawthorne dead. Fallon dazed, her arm bleeding. An unspeakable scene, smoke hanging. Over 100 people are down -- dazed, bleeding, flattened.
I need a doctor!/I need help!/ Somebody! Help! NAMES called aloud:

Dad? Mom? Jewell turns: BYSTANDERS and MORE COPS are RUSHING TOWARD THE SCENE NOW. People reaching for cell phones. A TURKISH CAMERAMAN races in, ready to start shooting. But the guy COLLAPSES from a heart attack, dead on the spot. More people SCREAM. We WHIP BACK TO: Jewell, his eyes wide. There’s Green among the DOWNED COPS. Jewell gets to his feet, his balance shaky. He heads for Green, while stumbling past Shaw, and: Jewell gets to Green who is face-down, his jersey and flesh torn open by shrapnel.
How bad?

I’m fine, I’m fine. Go! More GROANS around them, more screams, more cries. Over Jewell’s shoulder, the tattered SOUND and LIGHT TOWER -- still standing, but its front side has been blown off. (CONTINUED)
44 45 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 35.

You hang tough, brother. Help’s coming. Green nods. Blood everywhere... We hear our first SIREN now. Jewell moves toward Silver as: Incredibly, amid all this chaos, he sees TECHS racing back into the blown-up tower. He hurries over.
What the hell’re you doing?
I left my laptop in there.
You can get it in the morning.
It’s got all my WORK on it! I got shit in there, too!

NO ONE is going back inside this building until we know it’s structurally sound. There could be a SECOND device! The Techs turn away. Jewell hurries toward Silver, who's bleeding badly -- passing a dazed Bill Miller as: Miller numbly takes his WALLET out of his back pocket, to find a piece of SHRAPNEL stuck inside. His GBI BADGE just saved his ass. Literally. Shaw awakens. We CRANE UP to take in all this chaos. Panic, blood, terror, people running, ambulances speeding TOWARD us. A nightmare. And Jewell is in the middle of it all. We --

ONE HOUR LATER -- The BRASS STATUE where Alice Hawthorne had posed for a picture now has NAILS embedded in it. Another NAIL has been embedded in a KODAK CAMERA lying unclaimed on the ground. A NEWS CREW gets a shot of it. Barricades have been erected. EMTs at work. AMBULANCES everywhere. And a cluster-fuck by the TOWER -- guys from GBI, APD, ATF, USOC, arguing. Shaw’s among them, his forehead bleeding. (CONTINUED)
45 46 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 36.
This is homicide. It’s ours.
This park is state property. That makes it ours!
You guys can BOTH get the fuck out of here. This is ATF.
No, YOU get the fuck out of here! This is OUR crime scene! Jewell walks past, dialing his cell.
(into cell) Mom, it’s me. They had a bomb go off down here, but I am okay. Turn on the TV. Love you.

Atlanta locked down. BARRICADES. MILITARY VEHICLES. RAMPARTS. A red CNN glow behind every window. We FIND: Ron Martz of the AJC, shaken, standing at the gate of Centennial Park as wounded are rushed past. It’s an echo of Iraq for him. Suddenly, someone puts a hand on his: Kathy -- smiling warmly. Martz appreciates it. She shuts her eyes, lowers her head.
Dear God... whoever did this... Prayer. Nice. Martz shuts his eyes, too.
Please let us find him, before anyone else does. Martz’s eyes snap open. NOT praying this prayer anymore.
And please, whoever he is... let him be fucking interesting. Amen. She releases Martz’s hand. He shakes his head.  47 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 37.

Jewell stands outside the tattered tower. The ambulances are gone now. The wounded have all been moved. But the barricades remain, swarmed by LAW ENFORCEMENT. Eerie. He watches as they collect evidence and interview people. At his feet is a shard of what used to be HIS BENCH. He looks around, then pockets it. A souvenir.
Are you Jewell? Jewell whips around, caught. Oh, shit. Here comes TIM BARKER of AT&T, all business.
Yes, sir. I was just --
I’m Tim Barker, AT&T Media Relations. Did I hear this right? You discovered the bomb? Oh. Jewell relaxes, pleased.
Yes, sir.
That makes you a hero. Know that?
I was just doing my job, sir.

That’s a nice thing to say, Richard. But we’ve had a lot of requests from people who’d like to talk to you. Would that be okay? (as Jewell just stares) CNN. Katie Couric. Those types. Your superior gave the okay.
There were a LOT of police personnel here, sir, clearing people out. Wasn’t just me.

You’re the one who spotted the package. You’re the one people want to hear from.  RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 38. 48 INT. “MAKEUP” TENT - DAY (LATER) 48 Jewell sits in a makeup chair. The MAKEUP GIRL finishes him off.
You’re all set. They’1ll come get you in just a minute.
Thanks. She leaves. He regards himself in the mirror -- about to go on “The Today Show.” He gulps hard, looks up at GOD:

God. I know you got other things on your mind right now, like catchin’ the guy who did this and all. But, seein’ as this is live TV, and I feel like I’m about to throw up inside my mouth... could you please make sure I don’t say anything stupid out there? Amen.
49 INT. BOBI’S APT. - DAY 49 Bobi is watching TV, beaming, because Jewell is on the air, LIVE, being interviewed by Katie Couric.
(on TV) Do you feel like a hero?
(on TV) No, ma’‘am. I’m just a guy who did the job he was trained to do...

(so proud) My boy... 50 INT. BRYANT’S PRIVATE OFFICE - MORNING 50 Bryant’s at his desk, HEARING the Jewell interview via the TINY TV on Nadya’s desk in the next room -- finds it borderline unbelievable, but kind of thrilling.
Good for you, Radar...  51 52 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 39. EXT. CENTENNIAL PARK - “TODAY” SET - MORNING 51 Jewell leaves the set with Barker, passing TWO APD COPS:
Good job, Richard. Way to go, man. Acceptance from real cops. Very gratifying.
Hey, I was workin’ with a couple guys who were injured: Green? Silver? Miller? They okay?
Word is, all the cops are expected to make a full recovery.
Well, that’s great. Thanks. Then a GUY IN A GREAT SUIT approaches. Barker smiles.
Richard, there’s someone I'd like you to meet. This is Mister Brenner from Bernstein & Crane. You know that company? They publish books.
Nice to meet you, sir.

Hello, Richard. I’d like to talk to you about your story. Ya free? Jewell feels a bit like he’s floating now. INT. BOBI’S APT. —- KITCHEN - DAY 52 Bobi bakes more pound cakes. TV on, LOCAL NEWS, another Jewell interview. TV is also on in the living room -- ABC -- yet another Jewell interview. He enters.
You’re everywhere! And the phone never stops. I need a secretary!
Momma, a guy from New York just asked me if I wanted to write a book! (CONTINUED)
52 53 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 40.
Well, lah-dee-da!
I don’t even have to DO anything. Someone else thinks it up and types it and all; I just say yes or no to stuff. For money!

You’re a ROCK STAR! Tom Brokaw was even talking about you! Jewell beams, catches a glimpse of himself in a MIRROR -- And there it is, for the first time ever: PRIDE -- a hero looking back at him. Feels GREAT. But...
Movement. Urgency. Agents responding to real crisis. BRUCE HUGHES, the SAC (Spec. Agent In Charge) of this field office, approaches Tom Shaw:
Shaw. You doin’ okay?
Not really, sir. Fucking bomb went off on my watch. My fucking park.
We didn’t have enough eyeballs there. That’s on us. Let’s just catch the son of a bitch, yeah? Tom Shaw nods, grateful. That helped.
I need you to get out to Habersham County -- background on a former sheriff's deputy. Might have some connection to the bombing.
Oh? Who is he? Bruce Hughes pauses, knowing this is NOT a small piece of news:
The security guard. (CONTINUED)
53 54 55 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 41.
BANG. That fast, Tom Shaw has his man. And it’s Jewell.

Jewell gets out of his PICKUP, ready for work. Instantly, PEOPLE notice him. PARENTS point him out to their KIDS. That feels great. And shockingly new. He passes a U.S. SWIMMER (we recognize the SWEATS on the guy); the Swimmer nods with great respect and:

Way to go, man. Made us all real proud. Respect from an ATHLETE. Jewell beams, thrilled. But: INT. PIEDMONT UNIVERSITY - CLEERE’S OFFICE - DAY 55 Dr. W. Ray Cleere (who fired Jewell in this very office not long ago), studies Jewell’s old file. Opposite Cleere... is Tom Shaw.
I want to be clear -- I haven't accused him of anything.
I understand.

I just... I see the attention he’s getting; it’s the KIND of attention he was always seeking here when he was harassing students, pulling people over on the highway. Crazy behavior. And I decided if my fears were correct -- if he WASN’T actually the hero they’re makin’ him out to be -- and I'd had information pertinent to that fact which I’d failed to bring to light? It could jeopardize lives.
Dr. Cleere, you did the right thing, calling. And we will look into it. Cleere nods. We FIND a PHOTO of Jewell, which BECOMES:  56 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 42.
The PHOTO of Jewell fills a screen. Bruce Hughes sighs:
Why is the Goddamn ACOG re-opening that park? We don’t have shit. Ten other SENIOR FBI GUYS (and Tom Shaw) in here. An ERASURE BOARD reads “CENTBOM.” Tension, pressure...
Okay. I want to hear more about Jewell. Patrick? All eyes on PATRICK WILLIAMS from the Behavioral Sciences Team --

When I look at Jewell, I think about the bomb scare at the L.A. Olympics in ‘84: a bag left ona bus by the same cop who then discovered it. And the fires in Idaho this summer -- started by a firefighter who wanted the credit for putting them out. There is a profile that emerges, the false hero. Tom Shaw believes that to his core. The whole room does.

In interviews, Jewell’s account of the bombing seems vague, and he looks uncomfortable discussing the victims. I also found his mentioning on TV that he was hoping to get back into law enforcement a bit inappropriate. There’s a lot here that’s troubling. And everything Agent Shaw has learned about him does sync-up with this profile.
You agree with that, Tom?
I do, sir. Bruce Hughes digests that... Then:
Let’s put eyes on him. 56  RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 43. 57 INT. BRYANT’S OFFICE - DAY 57 Bryant reads the paper, annoyed by the society page.
Fools’ names and fools’ faces. Nadya leans in, mildly floored:
Watson? (as Bryant waits) Got a call for you.
Is it Bill Gates randomly wondering if I need a million dollars? ‘Cause if so, yes.
It’s Richard Jewell. Bryant laughs, thinks she’s kidding. She isn’t.
‘Richard Jewell’ Richard Jewell?
Yes.
I see. Uh, okay. She disappears to her desk. Then LINE 1 lights up.
(into phone) Hello?
58 INT. BOBI’S APT. - SAME TIME 58 Jewell on the phone.
(into phone) Mister Bryant? I’m sorry to bother you, just got your number from Information. I hope you remember me. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 44.
(into phone) Richard, you're a national hero now. You can call me Watson.
(into phone) Oh. Thank you, sir. How are you? How’s your family?
(into phone) We’re all fine. I see you've moved up from video games!
(into phone) Didn't mean to, but yeah, guess I did.
(into phone) Well, good job, that’s a prideful thing. What can I do for you?
(into phone) Sir, have you ever done a book deal? Do you do that?
(into phone) Contracts are contracts. Why?
(into phone) This bomb thing. Got some New York guys asking me to write a book and I don’t know anything about that, so I thought maybe you could help me.
(into phone) I’d be happy to.
(into phone) Are you not at the U.S. Small Business Admin anymore? I tried there first.
(into phone) No. I got outta there. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 45.
(into phone) Oh. How come?
(into phone) Lifestyle decision. You just make sure not to sign anything until I see it first. Okay? We’ll start there.
‘Kay. Thanks, Watson. Bryant ends the call. Kind of a stunned smile. Nadya leans in, pretty excited, as --
Shaw, a drink before him, signals for a refill, as --
Must be a lotta heat on you guys. Shaw turns. Here’s Kathy, in a shorter-than-short skirt and a barely-buttoned blouse. Shaw grins.
No more so than usual.
Right, just your average deadly bombing on U.S. soil during an Olympics. Happens all the time.
Pressure’s on you guys, too. CNN’s got it wall-to-wall. Might account for your shorter-than- usual skirt and your tits-ablaze blouse.
Admit it, though. I’m smoking hot! The truth? Yes, he thinks she’s smoking hot.
Give me something I can print, Tom. I’1l treat you right.
Sorry. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue)
I know the Bureau's looking at someone.
What makes you think so?
Sources. Friends. Who is it?
If you couldn’t fuck it out of them, what makes you think you can fuck it out of me? She smiles, wets her lips. Shaw exhales... then: Shaw hesitates. She leans in -- that open blouse.
Ya know what people don’t get, Kathy? How much work goes in to making a case. It’s effort, 24-7.
You’re right. So educate me.

head_text.subj: I WON'T HAVE THIS SCREWED UP.

text: There was a slaughter out here. It’s a miracle there weren’t more fatalities.
I wouldn’t run it unless I had independent corroboration from a second source. That would put us in a different zone, as you know. (her hand drifting) Tom. You’re about to burst.
First time in my life I ever wished I was gay. Kathy smiles... then Shaw gives it up: WHOA.

The Bureau's looking at the security guard. Jewell. Kathy freezes. Did I hear that wrong? Trying to calm herself, she takes out her notepad. 46. 59 Kathy lets her hand drop onto his lap. He’s hard as an anvil. (CONTINUED)
59 60 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 47.
You always look at the guy who found the bomb, just like you always look at the guy who found the body. But Jewell’s got a bad past. Fits the hero-bomber profile to a ‘T.’

Yes, yes, shit! The fat loser living with his mother! So obvious! Why didn’t I see it?! (her mind racing) This puts a clock on things. Wanna get us a room? Or should we just go down to my car? INT./EXT. BOBI’S APT. - FRONT DOOR - NIGHT 60 Bobi opens the door to find -- Bill Miller on the doorstep -- Jewell’s GBI buddy. Bobi’s thrilled.
It's so good to see you, Bill! It’s been a while.
It's nice to see you, Bobi! Where’s the hero?
He’s right here. Come on in! Bobi, proud as hell, welcomes him in... INT. BOBI’S APT. - DINING ROOM - NIGHT 61 They’re onto second helpings of lasagna now --
What kinda charge ya figure it was?
Not sure what kinda explosive the guy used -- black powder, match heads, maybe some kinda chlorate, packed with nails. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 48.

Funny thing is, when those drunks moved it, they saved a bunch of lives, ‘cause it was s’posed to blow OUT, into a crowd, for maximum casualties. They left it on its BACK, so it exploded upwards, most of the ordnance going into the sky. There’s nails from it on rooftops all over downtown. You'd typically have a battery and a timing device, could even be a simple clock. I...
Miller is in the back of a moving van, a sickened look on his face. He unbuttons his shirt and we see why: He was wearing a WIRE during that dinner. A FBI OPERATIVE removes it gently...
Kathy glides through, stopping at Martz’s desk.
Sweetie, I need you to do one of those better-word-things you do.
You mean rewrite you?
Yes. You know I write like a brick. And this one’s kinda special.
What is it?
Oh, nothing. Just the FBI is looking at Richard Jewell as the bomber... Martz’s eyes go wide. We --
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 49.
Managing Editor JOHN WALTER listens as Kathy pitches him. Staffers looking on.

‘The security guard who first alerted police to the pipe bomb that exploded in Centennial Olympic Park is the target of the federal investigation into the incident that resulted in two deaths and injured more than 100.’ Her reading CONTINUES OVER: 65 INT. BOBI’S APT. - DAY 65 Bobi bakes a pound cake. Jewell playing a video game.

‘Richard Jewell, 33, a former law enforcement officer, fits the profile of the lone bomber. This profile generally includes a frustrated white man who is a former police officer, member of the military, or police ‘wannabe’ who seeks to become a hero.’ 66 INT. AJC - 8TH FLOOR —- NEWSROOM - MOMENTS LATER 66 Kathy continues pitching the piece to Walter:
‘Jewell has become a celebrity in the wake of the bombing, making appearances on the “Today Show” and’ --
-- Bureau knows you have this?
My guy says it’s everywhere now; the networks have it. CNN has it.
I got a guy at GBI said the same thing. Bureau’s looking at Jewell. (CONTINUED)
66 67 68 69 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 50.
Then why isn’t anyone reporting it? Does anybody feel we’re getting worked here?
Goddamn it, John, these are OUR Olympics! If we’re not gonna lead on this story, what the fuck are we DOING here? Walter exhales hard... and decides:
Okay. Tear up the afternoon edition and replate the front page. We’re running it.
PATRONS watch a big-screen TV as the STORY EXPLODES: BREAKING NEWS on CNN -- The ANCHOR holds up a copy of the AJC and reads the piece verbatim over the air.
(into camera) ‘The security guard who first alerted police to the pipe bomb...’ Shock on every face. People reaching for cell phones...

Kathy enters. CNN is blaring from TVs. And: Everyone in here turns... and APPLAUDS her. 100 CO- WORKERS, even the women who resent her short skirts. It's a journalism mountaintop. RESPECT FROM HER PEERS, at last. Kathy beams with humility and gratitude.
Tom Shaw is at work as the story breaks. Everyone around him LIVID. And Tom Shaw knows he’s a dead man. Bruce Hughes storms in, irate. Everyone turns. (CONTINUED)
69 70 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 51.
Who the fuck leaked this investigation to the AJC?! Of course, no one confesses. Tom Shaw eyes his shoe- tops.
Tom Shaw's eyes go wide. Instant terror. How do they know?
Sir?
Get Jewell in here. Non- confrontational interview. TODAY. Bennet has a tactical approach. Tom Shaw’s heart begins to beat again. He looks to Dan Bennet. We RETURN TO:
TV OFF. Jewell sleeps. Bobi bakes more pound cakes... A firm KNOCK at the front door. Jewell awakens, rises, goes to the door... Opens it:
Hello? Shaw and Bennet stand here. Oddly, we hear HUNDREDS OF VOICES shouting from the PARKING LOT:
Richard! Richard! But Jewell can’t see anyone from here.
Richard Jewell?
Yes?
Special Agents Dan Bennet and Tom Shaw, FBI. Ya got a minute?
Sure! What can I do for you? (CONTINUED)

FROM ACROSS the newsroom we watch Kathy and Ron Martz type madly, like Woodward and Bernstein... Then: INSERTS: One HEADLINE after another -- burying Jewell, th FBI's case building but without any evidence. Front page after front page, IN our face, slamming loudly, then -- INT. BOBI’S APT. - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 121 Bryant, Jewell, and Bobi sit -- dejected and silent. The place smells STALE. Feels like a PRISON... Bryant looks out the window: The HORDE is out there, as always. So are FIVE FBI SEDANS. Jewell turns a BASEBALL GAME up loud. Things are feeling a little CRAZY in here.
Jewell pays at the counter. TWO GUYS behind him in line stare: That’s HIM! Jewell can feel their excitement. (CONTINUED)
122 123 124 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 80.
Now, you ain’t gonna blow us up, are ya? No reply from Jewell, just a wounded smile. He gets his change, takes away TWO BAGS, and exits.
Thank you.

Jewell emerges. Bryant waits here, in Jewell’s PICKUP. So do FIVE FBI SEDANS. Oddly, Jewell heads for one of them -- the one that Shaw is in. Bryant tightens: What’s Jewell doing? Jewell taps on the sedan window. Shaw rolls the window down. What the??? --- as Jewell hands over one of the two bags of donuts.
Thought you guys might be hungry.
Uh... we can’t accept these. Across the street, 100 PHOTOGRAPHERS CAPTURE IT ALL...
It’s not a bribe or anything. I just know stakeouts suck.
Would you take them, please? Disappointed, Jewell collects the bag and walks away. INT. JEWELL’S PICKUP — CONTINUOUS ACTION 124 Jewell gets in. Bryant livid.
What the hell was that?
It’s a cop thing.
A: You don’t need any more donuts. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 81.
I’m sick of everyone calling you fat. B: You don’t need any more attention.
You never done a stakeout.
Richard, you just gave the world a headline: ‘Jewell Tries to Buy Off Cops with Donuts!’ I can’t help you if you’re gonna let them make a joke out of you.
Thought if the cops liked me more, they might not be so hard on us. Bryant freezes. That felt so sad and heartbreaking...

They’re NEVER gonna like you. Let’s just get ‘em to respect you. Okay? He opens Jewell’s GLOVE COMPARTMENT to stuff the bag in - ... which is when Bryant sees a small TEDDY BEAR inside. Huh? Bryant just stares, then extracts the Teddy bear.
What's this?

Oh. I used to work a lot of car wrecks when I was in the sheriff's office. Sometimes there'd be kids involved, and they’d always be scared. So, I kept Teddy bears in my trunk, to calm ‘em down. Just became a habit. There it is -- Jewell’s pure, innocent kindness again. And Bryant is ashamed, feeling like a major asshole.
Never know when you’re gonna happen upon a car wreck, I guess.
No, sir. Bryant puts the bear away, shuts the glove compartment. (CONTINUED)
124 125 126 127 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 82.
Let’s keep this between us, so they don’t accuse you of being a child molester. Jewell starts up the truck, pulls out -- right past Shaw. Bryant tosses the DONUTS into Shaw’s window.
Live a little. We LEAVE the lot. The FIVE FBI CARS follow. Infuriating. INT. BOBI’S APT. - LIVING ROOM - DUSK (MINUTES LATER) 125 Bobi watches TV. Bryant enters without a knock, RESOLVED.
Get up, Bobi. I’m taking you two to dinner.
Where’s Richard?

In the car. I can’t sit in this apartment anymore. Let’s go. INT. BRYANT’S 4RUNNER (MOVING) - EVENING 126 Bryant drives. Bobi rides up front, Jewell in back. Those same FIVE FBI SEDANS trail behind. He pulls into:
The FIVE SEDANS are forced to follow. Bobi looks around.
Watson, where’re we goin’?
You just sit tight, Bobi. She shrugs. Bryant makes a SWOOPING LEFT. Huh? --.- and all the FBI SEDANS follow. He makes a SWOOPING RIGHT now. Bobi and Jewell confused - (CONTINUED)
127 128 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 83.
But all the sedans follow... And now we get it. He’s just fucking with them. Bryant drives a little faster. They have to follow suit.

Oh, my Lord... +.. we watch as Bryant drives in a big CIRCLE, until he’s actually behind the sedans. Bobi starts to laugh, waving at the sedans -- all these agents trying to do surveillance, hopelessly fouled now.

You see that, Richard?! And Jewell laughs, his first bright moment in a while. Bryant beaming, driving the sedans in circles... INT. BLIND WILLIE’S - NIGHT (LATER) 128 A JAPANESE MAN stands on a small stage, mic in hand, singing a KARAOKE version of “Rebel Yell.” Pretty awful. But Jewell, Bobi, and Bryant have finally found a place to be unrecognized.
I like it in here, Watson.

I like how you handle yourself generally, Watson. Ain’t afraid of them agents, that’s fer sure. A WAITER brings a cocktail for Bryant. Beer for Bobi. Coca-Cola for Jewell. They half-toast to one another...
We lucked out, karaoke night.
You know, Richard can sing.
That right?
Sure can.
Momma... (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 84.
What? He sang all the time when he was young. And he was good. “Rebel Yell” ends. Polite applause. The stage is empty.
Why don’t you show him, Richard?
I don’t think I should...
Why not? You’re certainly good enough for this establishment.
I had enough attention lately. Court of public opinion and stuff.
I don’t see any cameras, do you? Please? For me?
Momma...
You won't get up there and sing for your gray-haired momma like you did in school? Jewell tightens, weighing it. Bryant eyeing him... Then:
Let’s hear it, son. That surprised Jewell -- kind of surprised Bryant, too.

Really? (as Bryant nods) Awright, then. He rises, unaware that -- Kathy just drifted in, without fanfare. She lingers by the bar, out of Jewell’s eye-line as -- He gets up on stage. This has to go badly, right? He picks a song, grabs the microphone. NO ONE recognizing him. The song starts. Bon Jovi. Jewell air-guitars... (CONTINUED)
128 129 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 85.
The first strains of “Wanted Dead Or Alive.” Then --

It’s all the same/Only the names have changed -- Guess what? He’s great. Bryant can’t believe it. Thrilled. Kathy’s kind of shocked, too. Bobi puffs up a bit: See? Around them, PEOPLE start to notice the guy on stage, pouring his heart out: Richard Jewell, singing Bon Jovi to the dive bar. Their heads sway to the beat. Kathy, despite herself, just started to rethink things... A GUY at the next table (Japanese-American, wears a suit, call him KEN) leans over to Bryant:
That guy is really good.
I know.
And he’s a dead ringer for Richard Jewell! Bobi nearly gasps, but:
Yeah. He gets that a lot. Ken CHEERS LOUDER, as:

‘Cause I’m a cowboy/On a steel horse I ride/I’m wanted/Dead or alive... INT./EXT. BRYANT’S CAR/MONACO APTS. - PARKING LOT - NIGHT Bryant pulls up in front of the building. The HORDE awaits out here, like sharks...
Thanks, Watson.
G'night, you two. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 86.
A beat. Jewell doesn’t want to get out. Truth is, something shifted tonight. Bobi can see it.
We're lucky to have you, Watson. And I don’t just mean that legally.
Mom --
No. I’m gonna say it. Richard never had a man around to look out for him. His daddy wasn’t worth a pitcher of warm spit, that’s for sure. Walked right out on us.
Listen, I’m just trying to get my hundred bucks back.

And then he had a step-daddy who I thought might be a good man and father, but HE up and left us, too. Ain’t no man ever stood up for him. It’s why Richard wanted to be a cop -- to take care of people, ‘cause he knew what being forgotten about felt like. And now here you are, taking on all this for him. It touches me, Watson. Bryant nods... looks at the HORDE out there... and says something that’s been on his mind for too long:
Richard... We have to get you a proper defense attorney. Huh? That hovers. Jewell eyes Bobi...
I don’t wanna do that.
This is out of my league. You know that. A month ago I was doing real estate closings.
You’re the only one I trust. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 87.

Well, I don’t always trust cops, but sometimes I NEED one. And right now you need a defense attorney who specializes in capital crimes. Preferably from a small firm that the Bureau respects. That’s not me.
It’s not me, either.
Listen, Goddammit --

I’m not walkin’ into court with a team of lawyers behind me like O.J. That makes people think you did it! .-. which is when his voice breaks. He stops short... +... WILL NOT LET HIMSELF CRY. But it’s close. And Bryant is stopped cold. This argument just ended.
We should get inside.

Night, you two. They get out. Bryant watches them go. The MOB descends, instantly suffocating Jewell and Bobi. Jewell grabs her hand, plowing through the bodies -- Bryant looks sickened. He gets out of his car, SHOUTS:

You’re killing him! Every Goddamn one of you KILLING A PERSON. Aren’t you ashamed of yourselves? No one in the mob replies. But Jewell and Bobi appreciated it. They make it safely into their apartment. Door shuts. The mob dissipates. Bryant gets back in his car, pulling out of the lot, then onto Buford Highway...  130 131 132 133 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 88.
Kathy, eyeing her watch, begins to walk -- FAST -- from the site of the explosion.

Kathy arrives at the SIX PAY-PHONES and eyes her watch. Just realized the same thing Bryant did: The math doesn’t work. Jewell couldn’t have done it. Oh. INT. BOBI’S APT. - FRONT DOOR - DAY 132 The door opens. Here’s Bryant, with more bad news:
They want your hair now. And your palm prints, the damn bastards. Jewell sags. Bobi’s not around. We --
INT. BOBI’S APT. - DAY (LATER) 133 Jewell sits while HAIR STRANDS are plucked from his head by a uniformed MEDIC in gloves. One at a time. Bryant watches, fuming. Bennet and Shaw supervise. TV on.
25 pulled, 25 combed. Medic nods. Bryant looks like he might kill somebody.
I want you to know, you might have a warrant for this -- but if you wanted to do this to me you’d have to fight me. You’d have to beat the shit out of me.
Not too lawyerly, Counselor. Today's AJC sits on the table. Its HEADLINE: “Jewell Kept Souvenirs of the Bomb in Mother’s Apartment.” On that TV, over a PICTURE OF JEWELL -- (CONTINUED)
133 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 89.
(on TV) The guy was seen with a homemade BOMB at his home a few days before! Bryant angrily shuts the TV OFF.

Let’s just get this over with before my mom comes home. I wouldn’t want her seein’ this. Bryant crosses to that framed PORTRAIT of Jewell in his HABERSHAM COUNTY DEPUTY SHERIFF’S UNIFORM. He adjusts the frame as if it had been askew, to call their attention to it.
Tell me, Richard, you still proud to be law enforcement?
I just wish I’d done my job better that night. I wish I’d gotten everybody far enough away. Maybe if I had, I wouldn’t be sitting here right now. Bryant eyes Shaw and Bennet.
You’re right. He’s a monster. Have you dummies done the math yet on the call from the pay phone?
Fuck the pay phone. My clients are the people who were in that park. And they deserved not to have their fucking heads blown off.
I actually feel sorry for you guys. When the real bomber does it again, and the country asks, ‘Where was the FBI?’ You’re gonna say, ‘We were busy getting hair samples from Richard Jewell’?
Shaw doesn’t reply.
I’m done here. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 90.
Good. (a beat) Thanks for the professional courtesy, Richard. Ya know, one cop to another.
There’s the door. They leave. Medic follows. Bryant steaming.
We need to start being a little less solicitous and a lot more righteous with these bastards.
It's just hairs. They’1ll grow back.

head_text.subj: WHY DOESN'T THIS SHIT MAKE YOU AS

text: ANGRY AS IT MAKES ME Jesus!
Just ‘cause someone’s not yelling doesn’t mean they’re not angry.
You’re angry?
Course.
Then stop being such a doormat! Stop tryin’ to be their best friend! I’m tired of it.
I’m tired of stuff, too!
Yeah? Like what? (as Jewell’s silent) Like what? Jewell walks into the kitchen, leaving Bryant alone. We hear a CABINET opening. Bryant calls out:
You reach for a cookie right now and I’m gonna KILL someone! (CONTINUED)
133 134 135 136 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 91.
We hear the cabinet close. INT. BOBI’S APT. - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS ACTION 134 The DOORBELL RINGS. Bryant crosses to it, opens it.
What. Nadya stands here. On the doorstep. Grim as hell.
What’s wro-- She covers his mouth, urgently.

Sssssshhhh. She steps INSIDE. Bryant at a loss. Jewell appearing. Nadya shuts the door and holds up a NOTE: “Our office is bugged -- in the ceiling. Our phones are also bugged. THIS PLACE IS PROBABLY BUGGED TOO.” Bryant and Jewell just stare. Jewell whispers:
How can they keep doin’ this, Watson?
That's easy. They can do it because you don’t matter. That felt ugly but true, and it hangs there. cUT TO:
CLOSING CEREMONIES. America bidding farewell.
This huge space, EMPTY now. Just a meager clean-up crew.  137 138 139 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 92.
Empty. The games are a memory.
Empty. No more sound and light tower. No sign of the crime. But a space is being measured for a SCULPTURE to commemorate the tragedy.

Shaw sits alone, getting hammered. Then -- Kathy appears, takes the barstool beside him. Shaw’s expression instantly hardens into cold contempt. Kathy signals to the bartender for Shaw’s drink to be refilled. Shaw doesn’t react.
I can’t fucking believe you’d have the nerve to sit here.
Jewell couldn’t’ve placed the call. (as Shaw glares) The math is wrong. I tried to cover the distance between the site and the pay phones; he couldn’t’ve --
We know that.
You know that?
Just means he had an accomplice.
An accomplice.
Sure. Why not?
The ‘Lone Bomber’ profile. The wannabe cop. With an accomplice? (CONTINUED)
139 140 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 93.
First, profiles are a jumping-off point. And Oklahoma City had two bombers, remember?
So who is it?
Right. I’m gonna tell you. After you burned me like that.
Fine. I’11l just write that the case against Jewell is starting to weaken. Bad facts, et cetera.
Where did you get this idea that I work for you? Or that we work together? In fact, I don’t know why I’m even talking to you.
(knowing grin) I know why. He gets up to go, leaving his Scotch on the bar.
Whoa. Never saw you leave one un- finished before.
It's yours. Choke on it.

The feeling is foggy -- a MEMORY... or a DREAM -- We’re outside the SOUND AND LIGHT TOWER, one minute before that ALICE PACK will explode. COPS move people away. Confusion and urgency. SOUND dipping in and out.

He’s looking at all these COPS and BYSTANDERS, who are about to be injured. There’s Alice Hawthorne, who is about to die. And Jewell knows it... So: He crawls under that bench and pulls the ALICE pack into him, wrapping himself around it like a human bomb blanket. (CONTINUED)
140 141 142 143 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 94,

He knows what’s coming -- a hero’s death. Shuts his eyes, can hear the bag TICKING... 5, 4, 3, 2, 1... Then: It EXPLODES. An electric white LIGHT. Jewell literally coming apart in an eruption of violence and sound as -- INT. BOBI’S APT. -— JEWELL’S BEDROOM - NIGHT (REALITY) 14 Jewell’s eyes slam open... We --
Dave Dutchess eats a burger, all alone... until: Bennet and Shaw plant themselves opposite him, badges out. Quite an unpleasant surprise. Dutchess tightens.

Mister Dutchess. Ya got a minute? Dutchess sighs. We hear the beginnings of a HELICOPTER SOUND and MATCH THAT SOUND TO: INT. BOBI’S APT. - NIGHT (LATE) 143 On TV: a WWII movie. John Wayne. Muted. Outside, we hear a HELICOPTER hovering. Dutchess is here, opposite Jewell, Bobi, and Bryant. A feeling of shock and gloom hanging. And this is whispered:

-.. They’ve decided that since you couldn’t have placed the 9-1-1 call, you must’ve had a partner. They think that partner must be your homosexual boyfriend... which they’ve decided is probably me. That lands on the faces of everyone...
And they asked me to wear a wire.
Jesus...
Richard.
Sorry, ma’am. (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 95.

I told ‘em to shove it. I said you were a hero. They said, ‘If he’s really a hero, then he has nothing to worry about and neither do you.’ Also said one of your GBI buddies -- the one you made lasagna for when he came over -- he was wired, too. Got a LOT on you. That hurt Jewell deeply. He’s silent. Dutchess goes on:
(reluctantly) Um... There’s one other thing: They asked me if I’d ever had any experience with pipe bombs... I had to tell ‘em the truth. Bryant shuts his eyes without meaning to...
Ya know, little ones. We used to drop ‘em down groundhog holes when I was a kid in West Virginia.
David. My Lord...
I told ‘em this was years before I even met Richard. I said ita couple times. Still... I’m sorry.

It’s okay. But it’s not okay. They all know it. Outside, the sound of that HELICOPTER grows louder, closer... Bobi, depressed as hell, returns to the TV and UN-MUTES it. The sounds of a MOVIE BATTLE fill the room: WWII MORTAR ROUNDS and GUNFIRE erupting. But instantly --
Mom! Jewell LEAPS for the remote, turns the TV off.
How’s it gonna look if we’re in here watching movies about things blowing up?! Don’t you know they’re LISTENING! ? (CONTINUED)
143 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 96.
It's Bobi’s breaking point. She cries, runs to her room, slams the door. Jewell hurries over, gets there, knocks. Tries the handle. It’s locked. That HELICOPTER hovers.
Mom? I’m sorry. C’mon out. We can watch whatever you want. We hear Bobi’s sobs through the door. Jewell sinking.
Mom, please? Don’t stay in there. C’mon out. I won’t say nothin’ again. Please... Bryant and Nadya are left on the sofa, watching. Jewell keeps knocking on Bobi’s door --
Momma, please. Whatever you want -- Bobi opens the door, her eyes wet. The room goes SILENT, save for the sound of that Goddamn HELICOPTER overhead...
Richard, I’m scared.
Me, too, Momma.
I don’t know how to protect you from these people... He grabs her and hangs on. Bobi crying. Bryant and Nadya are across the room. Jewell eyes them, while still embracing his mother:
Three days, Watson. She’s had THREE DAYS to be proud of her son in her whole life. Now this. It ain’t right.

Then are you ready to start fighting back? Jewell nods. Yes, he’s ready. Not a small moment.  144 145 146 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 97. EXT./INT. CHILIVIS BLDG./BRYANT’S 4RUNNER - MORNING 144 This normally dead street is PACKED with PRESS today. Bryant drives Jewell into the driveway/alley of this building, his truck pushing the MOB aside as he smiles warmly for the cameras. Instantly, Nadya (in her car) and Dave Dutchess (in his) pull their cars NOSE-TO-NOSE in front of the alley, blockading it behind Bryant’s.

An odd, musty feel. Medieval TAPESTRIES hang on the wall. The shades are down because the MOB is right outside, in the alley -- so the room is sunless. Jewell sits, scared, as he’s wired by RICHARD RACKLEFF (50s, stocky, an FBI lifer, private sector now.)
Don’t see why we can’t just let the FBI do this.
You'd trust them with the results? Bryant opens the shades, waves out the window.
Who ya wavin’ to?
My new friends. An FBI VAN WITH BUBBLE-WINDOWS sits across the street.
Oh... Jewell’s anxiety RISES. Rackleff looks to Bryant: Get lost. Bryant eyes Jewell... then leaves. We --
The polygraph. The pressure cuffs. The needle. And:
Richard, whose idea was it for you to take a polygraph test? (CONTINUED)
146 147 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 98.
Watson’s. Jewell’s sweating. Rackleff eyes the readout.
How do you think you'll do on it?
Fine.

Do you know who put that bomb in Olympic Park? Bang. Their eyes meet. Jewell gulps. INT. BRYANT’S OFFICE - AN HOUR LATER 147 Nadya rests on the couch. Bryant looks out the WINDOW at that BUBBLE-WINDOW VAN and the MOB loitering outside.
Can you make some more of those pirozhkis? They were good.

Careful, Watson. In Russia if a woman makes pirozhkis twice for a man, it means they’re engaged. He grins. Rackleff enters, looking grim. Bryant springs toward him, motioning for him to be QUIET, pointing to the ceiling and indicating, “BUGS.” Rackleff nods, leans in, and WHISPERS:
Your boy is tanking. Hard. Bryant’s eyes widen. Nadya’s, too. Bryant WHISPERS BACK.
What does that mean?
His pulse, respiration, and skin conductivity are all off the charts -- all pointing to massive deception. And guilt. (CONTINUED)
147 148 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 99.
(oh, fuck) I. Uh...
Looks to be in the throes of an anxiety attack. Think you could calm him down a little?
A DONUT sits on a plate. Jewell, still wired-up, eyes it. Bryant beside him.
That mean I’m doin’ bad?
You’re doing fine. He thinks your blood sugar’s low. Eat it. Jewell bites into the donut, his eyes shutting.

Can I tell you something, Richard? (as Jewell shrugs) I went to Episcopal school as a kid. When I was in first grade, two nuns accused me of writing something unholy on my desk -- Jewell’s wondering: Why is he telling me this?

I hadn't done it, but they were sure I had. So they sent me back to kindergarten for a week -- just to humiliate me; then they asked me if I’d learned my lesson. I said I hadn’t because I hadn’t written on the desk in the first place. They asked me how I’d like to go sit in kindergarten for TWO weeks. I said, ‘You can throw me in there for a year -- I still can’t apologize for writing on the desk because I DIDN’T DO IT.’
You said that to nuns? (CONTINUED)
148 149 150 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 100.

I did. And they backed off. (re: FBI agents) Power doesn’t make a person right. Just tell your story, okay? Jewell nods, ready. INT. BRYANT’S OFFICE - 4 HOURS LATER - DAY 149 Bryant and Nadya sleep on the couch. Rackleff enters after a 4-HOUR test, exhausted. Nadya bolts up. Bryant waits, afraid to breathe.
(re: ceiling bugs) Maybe we should talk somewhere el--
He passed, highest level. ‘No deception indicated.’ Bryant wants to SHOUT or jump up and down. WE CAN WIN THIS THING. But he remains calm.
Thank you. Jewell appears, over Rackleff’s shoulder. Equally exhausted. Bryant eyes him. A shared moment...
The place thrums. Kathy at her desk. Martz walks by:
Anything interesting?
Gangland murder. Fucking yawn. Martz smiles, moves on. Kathy typing away, when --
Hi, Kathy. She looks up. And her eyes go wide -- because: HERE ARE BRYANT AND JEWELL. In the lions’ den. It comes to a halt. SILENCE. Kathy bracing herself -- (CONTINUED)
RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 101.
It was a souvenir from the bombing. Not the bomb. I said that when you asked for a quote.
I know. I’m sorry.

And who are you to make fun of a guy for staying with his mother? She was going to have SURGERY; he wanted to help her out. What’s weird about that? Tell him. (off no reply) While you’re at it you can tell him how he ‘approached this newspaper seeking publicity for his actions.’ Which he didn’t.
That was added during editorial.
Or how he fits the lone-bomber profile to a T, a ‘wannabe’ seeking to become a hero, when all he did was actually SAVE LIVES. Go ahead. We’ve got all day.
It was a mistake. I’m human.
So's Richard. With that, Bryant and Jewell head out. Kathy’s silent.
Bobi stands at a bank of microphones in a ballroom full of REPORTERS AND CAMERAS, Bryant just a few feet away as:

I am so very drained. I hope and pray to God that this never happens to anybody else. I do not think any of you can even begin to imagine what our lives are like. Shutters clicking, tape rolling. She goes on: (CONTINUED)
151 152 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 102.

They have taken all privacy from us. They have taken all peace. They watch and photograph everything we do. And why? Because my son did his job, because he saved people. Bobi looks to her side: Bryant, encouraging her...

I am asking the President for help today. Mister President, my son is a hero. I think the FBI knows that by now; the evidence makes it plain. If they do not intend to charge my son, please tell us. Please tell the world...
Bobi has one more sentence to get through. And it is --
Mister President, please clear my son’s name... And she loses it, breaking down in sobs, on camera. Bryant steps up, gently guiding her off the podium...
Bobi is a wreck. Bryant leads her into a large KITCHEN -- Jewell has been waiting here among BUSBOYS and CHEFS. Bobi falls into his arms, sobbing.
Momma, it’s awright...

I don’t know what happened. I thought I didn’t have any more tears left. Was that okay, Watson? Jewell and Bobi turn, and their jaws drop a bit because: Bryant’s eyes are wet, too. It shocks him as much as it shocks them. BUSBOYS watch. He gathers himself, then:
This all has to end now, Richard. I mean really end. You know that. (as Jewell nods) I’m calling the FBI. (CONTINUED)
Ya see? That’s what I’m talkin’ about. He just ain’t afraid of nobody.
You should hear what he says to nuns, Momma. Bryant studies Jewell -- a long beat -- then:
Let’s go show ‘em who you are.

AMERICAN FLAGS and American power. OCTOBER 6, 1996. INT. BOBI’S APT. —- SAME TIME — MORNING 154 Jewell stands at a mirror, putting on a tie. Big day. INT. BRYANT’S OFFICE - SAME TIME - MORNING 155 Bryant knots a tie, too. Definitely the best-looking suit we've seen him in yet. Very lawyerly. Nadya is at the desk, methodically packing all his FILES into a briefcase for him. Somber, but confident. Their eyes meet -- pure gratitude from Bryant.
Bryant’s 4 Runner pulls up. Jewell and Bryant emerge, in suits.
Jewell signs in, Bryant behind him. A SECURITY GUARD (old, black) waves them through a METAL DETECTOR.
Jewell and Bryant exit an elevator, led by Agent Bennet down a hallway to chairs outside a CONFERENCE ROOM door.
We'll be right with you. (CONTINUED)
158 RICHARD JEWELL - 6/20/19 (Full Blue) 104.
Agent Bennet enters the conference room, leaving Jewell and Bryant alone in this quiet corridor. Silence.
They’re going to ask to see me first. To set the ground rules.
I want them to know I’m not gay.

Believe me, you’ll get the chance to tell them. Shaw passes by, staring right through them before vanishing into the conference room. Jewell eyes the floor. Then a SOUND. He turns: It's an OFFICE CLERK... pushing a SUPPLY CART BY us. Pens, Scotch Tape, etc. Jewell watches him go, memories swirling. Bryant, too.
See if he’s got any Snickers bars, will ya? Jewell almost laughs. Almost.
You know what a 1001 is, Richard?
